bestBHT.bht: Some people's faith is like a plant with no deep roots, easily influenced by changing circumstances. They may initially seem sincere, but are ultimately unstable and superficial. When faced with trials and tribulations, they quickly fall away, unable to endure the pressure. Their faith lacks the essence of true grace, without the root of the matter. This serves as a reminder that authentic faith is rooted in embracing the Spirit of adoption and genuinely calling upon God as our Father. Let us examine our hearts and ensure our faith withstands life's challenges.

Henry Alford: The Greek word signifies not only ‘dureth for a while,’ but also ‘is the creature of circumstances,’ changing as they change.
St. Luke has, 'in time of temptation fall away,' thus accommodating themselves to that time.
Marvin Vincent: He is a creature of circumstances, changing as they change.
Tribulation is perhaps as accurate a rendering as is possible, being derived from tribulum, the threshing - roller of the Romans.
In both the idea of pressure is dominant, though qliyiv does not convey the idea of separation (as of corn from husk) which is implied in tribulatio.
John Calvin: Persecution and the cross lay open the vanity of those, who are slightly influenced by I know not what desire, but are not actually moved by earnest feelings of piety.

Those persons who take delight in the word of God, and cherish some reverence for it, do in some manner believe; for they are widely different from unbelievers, who give no credit to God when he speaks, or who reject his word.
Let us learn that none are partakers of true faith, except those who are scaled with the Spirit of adoption, and who sincerely call on God as their Father.
Philip Schaff: Yet hath he not root in himself. His apparent Christian life is rooted only in the temporary excitement about him.
Endureth for a while. The expression implies also: ‘is the creature of circumstances.’
Forthwith (as in the reception of the word) he is offended, or ‘taketh offence and falleth.’ Sentimental, superficial, changeful, one-sided professors of Christianity.
Archibald T. Robertson: What a picture of some converts in our modern revivals. They drop away overnight because they did not have the root of the matter in them. This man does not last or hold out.
Tribulation (θλιψεως). From θλιβω, to press, to oppress, to squeeze (cf. Matthew 7:14).
When, according to the ancient law of England, those who wilfully refused to plead, had heavy weights placed on their breasts, and were pressed and crushed to death, this was literally θλιψις.
John Gill: The word is not rooted in him, nor has he the root of the matter, or the truth of grace in him.
These try men's principles and professions, and whether the truth of grace is in them or not.
He shrinks back from it, does not care to take it up, and follow Christ; but drops his religion, and the profession of it; apostatises, falls away, and comes to nothing.
John Wesley: No deep work of grace: no change in the ground of his heart.
He has no deep conviction; and without this, good desires soon wither away.
He finds a thousand plausible pretences for leaving so narrow and rugged a way.

bhtAttempts.bht: Some people's faith is like a plant with no deep roots, easily swayed by changing circumstances. They may initially seem sincere in their Christian life, but are ultimately superficial and unstable. Furthermore, they quickly become offended and fall away when trials and tribulations arise, like weights pressing down on their chests. These individuals lack the root of the matter, the truth of grace, and their faith does not endure. This serves as a cautionary reminder that true faith is rooted in the Spirit of adoption and a sincere calling on God as our Father. Let us examine our hearts and ensure that our faith is not mere sentimentality, but a deep conviction that withstands the challenges of life.

When trials come, they quickly fall away, like being pressed and crushed. Their faith lacks the root of the matter, the truth of grace. This serves as a cautionary reminder that true faith is rooted in the Spirit of adoption and a sincere calling on God as our Father. Let us examine our hearts and ensure our faith withstands life's challenges.
